partial_orders.reason: Both edits reference the exact same symbol FENCE_RE. Edit 0 modifies the regex pattern definition of FENCE_RE by removing backtick support, and Edit 1 simplifies the usage of FENCE_RE by removing the inline code block handling and start parameter. These edits appear to be part of a coordinated refactoring where the regex pattern is simplified and its usage is correspondingly simplified. The changes reference the same symbol and could be made in either order since both are syntactically valid independently.

Both edits perform an identical textual substitution on the same type of syntactic construct. They both change the regex pattern from '(?:~{3,}|`{3,})' to '(?:~{3,})' in two different regex compile statements (FENCE_RE and FENCED_BLOCK_RE). This is a uniform, synchronized pattern substitution that would naturally occur as part of a single contiguous refactor to remove backtick fence support while keeping tilde fence support. Both edits target the same structural element (fence pattern in regex) and apply the exact same before→after transformation.

Both edits perform an identical textual substitution (changing '````' to '~~~~') within the same test method. This is a bulk-edit pattern where both changes are part of a single, contiguous refactor to update code block delimiters. The edits target the same type of syntactic construct (code block delimiters) with the exact same before→after pattern, making them part of a synchronized substitution that would naturally occur in one uninterrupted micro-task.

Edit 0 removes the definition of INLINE_CODE_RE (a compiled regex pattern), while Edit 1 removes all usage of that same INLINE_CODE_RE symbol in the code. The changed lines in Edit 1 explicitly reference the exact same symbol (INLINE_CODE_RE) that is being removed in Edit 0. After removing the definition in Edit 0, the usage in Edit 1 would cause a NameError at runtime, making the removal of usage the immediate next step. However, since Python allows referencing undefined variables at parse time (only failing at runtime), both edits can be staged in either order without causing parser errors. This creates a bi-directional relationship where either edit naturally prompts the other as the next mechanical step.

Both edits are part of a coordinated change to remove backtick (`) support for fenced code blocks and standardize on tilde (~) fencing. Edit 0 modifies the regex pattern to remove `{3,}` (backticks) from the fence pattern, keeping only `~{3,}` (tildes). Edit 1 updates a test case to use `~~~~` instead of ``````, ensuring the test remains valid after the regex change. These edits reference the same fencing mechanism - the regex pattern defines what constitutes a valid fence, and the test provides an example that must match that pattern. This is a synchronized refactoring where both changes are needed to maintain consistency between the implementation and its tests.
